pages_reviewed.rationale: The evidence cites 'gayatri' as corruption of 'Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak', but examining the extracted text shows this is actually a footnote reference issue, not OCR corruption in the main text. The main text contains legitimate German philosophical terms (eigentlichen, reinen, Geschmacksurtheils) with proper diacritics. 'Colours' is the British spelling (text is translated by British translator). The text is philosophical/technical with German terms intentionally preserved - this is expected for Kant scholarship. No actual garbled text in main body. The 'divisi-' is just a hyphenated line break for 'divisible'.
pages_reviewed.notes: Contains complex multilingual philosophical content with intentional foreign terms. Main text quality is good.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Evidence claims 'zierathen' is garbled, but this is actually the German term 'Zierathen' (ornaments) which Derrida is analyzing from Kant's original German text. The text explicitly shows: '[Zierathen: decoration, adornment, embellishment]' - this is intentional scholarly citation. 'Zeichnung' (design), 'Composition', 'innerlich' are all correct German terms being discussed. The philosophical terms 'parerga', 'parergon', 'ergon' are Greek terms central to Derrida's argument. This is multilingual philosophical scholarship, not OCR corruption.
pages_reviewed.notes: This is sophisticated multilingual philosophical text with intentional Greek and German terminology. The complexity is content, not corruption.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Genuine OCR errors visible: 'Hei-degger' split across line break badly, 'Uberfall' should have umlaut (Überfall), 'eigentlichen' appears fragmented. Error rate of 13% is legitimate. The text shows poor handling of line breaks and diacritics. While some German terms are intentional, the execution shows genuine quality issues with hyphenation and character encoding.
pages_reviewed.notes: Legitimate OCR quality issues with line break handling and diacritics.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Evidence cites 'problemes' but looking at text context ('quelques problemes de semiotique'), this is clearly a French title being cited - 'problèmes' is correct French. 'Souillac' is a proper place name (trumeau of Souillac - famous medieval sculpture). 'Echternach' is a proper place name (Echternach Gospels - famous manuscript). 'iconiques' is correct French (signes iconiques). The 'sometimesj' appears to be a minor artifact but in context of a complex scholarly footnote. Main text quality is actually good - this is multilingual scholarship.
pages_reviewed.notes: Multilingual scholarly text with intentional French citations and proper art historical references. One minor artifact but otherwise good.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Genuine severe corruption visible: 'tlVlty' is complete gibberish, 'besiisse' is clear OCR error (should be 'besässe' - German for 'possessed'). 'theo' truncation in critical context. Error rate of 14.2% is legitimate. The text contains genuine garbling that makes it difficult to read without significant correction. While some German terms are intentional (Fiktion, existiert), the actual corruption is severe.
pages_reviewed.notes: Severe corruption including gibberish text and character substitution errors.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Error rate of 38.7% is extreme. The French poetry section is severely corrupted - examining the text shows formatting issues with the verse section. While 'ponge', 'fleur', 'tete', 'politique' are legitimate French words, the evidence states 'OCR completely failed on formatted poetry/verse section' and 'French accents and diacritics lost'. The section is a Ponge poem that requires proper formatting and accents. This level of corruption in a critical textual element (poetry citation) justifies BAD classification.
pages_reviewed.notes: Extreme corruption in formatted poetry section with lost diacritics and formatting. Unreadable without restoration.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Looking at the extracted text: 'ohne ailes Interesse' (should be 'ohne alles Interesse' - minor typo), 'Widerstand' is correct German (resistance), 'Interesse' is correct German, 'nur negativ' is correct German, 'Sittlichkeit' is correct German (morality). The evidence cites 'counterinterest' which is actually a reasonable English translation, 'occu-' is just 'occupation' with line break. Most cited errors are either legitimate German terms or minor hyphenation. The page is readable and mostly correct.
pages_reviewed.notes: Mostly correct with intentional German philosophical terms. One minor typo ('ailes' vs 'alles') but otherwise good quality.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Evidence cites: 'werkhafte' (this is correct German - das Werkhafte des Werkes means 'work-character of the work'), 'uberfall' should be Überfall but is readable, 'hyle' is correct Greek philosophical term (ὕλη - matter), 'symbebekota' appears in quotes as Greek philosophical term (συμβεβηκότα - accidents/attributes), 'hyppostasis' in context appears to be 'hypokeimenon' discussion which is correct Greek (ὑποκείμενον). 'underneatb' typo for 'underneath' is minor, 'marcbe' for 'marche' (French) is minor. The text is complex multilingual philosophy but largely intact.
pages_reviewed.notes: Complex multilingual philosophical text with intentional Greek, German, and French terms. A few minor typos but content is substantially correct and readable.

pages_reviewed.rationale: All cited 'errors' are actually correct German philosophical terms being analyzed: 'seinem' (his/its), 'Verwandtschaft' (affinity/relationship), 'gleicht' (resembles), 'Zwischenstellung' (intermediate position), 'Eigenwiichsige' (self-sufficient/self-grown). The text is discussing Heidegger's German terminology about Zeug (equipment/product). 'Inadequation' is correct English. 'termediate' for 'intermediate' appears to be a minor typo. Error rate of 7.8% seems inflated by counting correct German terms as errors. Text is readable and philosophically sound.
pages_reviewed.notes: Scholarly discussion of German philosophical terminology. Terms are correct, not corrupted. One minor typo.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Genuine OCR corruption visible: 'vne' should be 'one', 'jjty' is garbled (likely 'ity' suffix), 'lnassive' should be 'massive', 'deternlinable' should be 'determinable'. These are clear character substitution errors (m→ln, j→i, etc.). While the evidence mentions 'not foreign language or footnote markers', these are actual OCR failures making the text difficult to parse. Error creates comprehension barriers in critical philosophical argumentation.
pages_reviewed.notes: Character-level OCR substitution errors that impair readability. Not multilingual content - actual corruption.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Genuine corruption: 'oiw' is corrupted Greek text (should be homoiōsis - ὁμοίωσις), character encoding failure. 'ible' fragments, 'sentative' (representative missing 'repre-' prefix), 'mea-' context unclear. The text shows OCR confidence issues with Greek transliteration and word fragments. These impact comprehension of philosophical argument about adequation and mimesis.
pages_reviewed.notes: Greek transliteration corruption and word fragmentation. Genuine OCR quality issues.

pages_reviewed.rationale: The evidence cites 'andranges' but in context 'standigen Andranges' is correct German (constant pressure/thrust). 'einfachen' is correct German (simple). 'crypted' is reasonable English (encrypted/hidden). The main cited error is 'discQurse' which is a clear OCR error (Q→o substitution) for 'discourse'. However, this is ONE error in otherwise readable text. Error rate of 10.7% seems inflated. The German terms are intentional and correct. Most of the text is high quality with one notable but isolated error.
pages_reviewed.notes: One clear OCR error ('discQurse') but otherwise correct text with intentional German terminology. Error rate appears inflated by counting correct terms.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Evidence cites: 'degger' (Heidegger truncated at line break - common hyphenation), 'jectivism' (subjectivism truncated at line break), 'ber' fragment (likely line break), 'alytic' (analytic truncated). These are all LINE BREAK artifacts, not OCR corruption. The actual text quality is good. 'aletheia' is correct Greek philosophical term (ἀλήθεια - truth/unconcealment). Error rate of 5.2% is at marginal boundary. The text is readable and the 'errors' are formatting/hyphenation issues, not character corruption.
pages_reviewed.notes: Line break/hyphenation artifacts, not OCR corruption. Content is correct and readable. Greek philosophical terms are intentional.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Pattern of 'fl-' prefix corruption is systematic: 'flideology' (ideology), 'fluseful' (useful), 'flpathos' (pathos), 'flattenuating' (attenuating). This is a consistent OCR artifact pattern, likely from formatting marks bleeding through (possibly from italics or quotation marks). Error rate 6.0%. While the pattern is predictable and potentially correctable, it creates comprehension barriers and represents genuine OCR failure. The systematic nature indicates a processing issue.
pages_reviewed.notes: Systematic OCR artifact with 'fl-' prefix corruption pattern. Genuine quality issue requiring correction.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Error rate 8.0% with genuine corruption in German text: examining context, German terms should be intact but show degradation. 'Loch' appears correct (hole) but evidence suggests surrounding context is corrupted. 'nicht' mangled, 'und' oddly placed indicates structural issues. The text discusses philosophical concepts (Unheimlichkeit, Anwesen/Abwesen) but execution is degraded. Given error rate and impact on German philosophical terminology which should be preserved accurately, classification is justified.
pages_reviewed.notes: Genuine corruption in German philosophical text. Error rate and impact on technical terminology justify BAD classification.

pages_reviewed.rationale: Evidence cites: 'tete' is correct French (tête - head), 'rendre' is correct French verb being discussed extensively ('se rendre'), 'quelqu' is truncated 'quelqu'un' (someone) which is grammatically correct truncation, 'nant' could be 'néant' (nothingness), 'disposant' is correct French (having at disposal). The text is analyzing French verb 'rendre' with multiple meanings - this is intentional wordplay, not corruption. Footnotes discuss translation complexities. Error rate 7.4% seems to count French terms as errors. Text is readable and philosophically coherent.
pages_reviewed.notes: French philosophical wordplay and translation discussion. Cited 'errors' are mostly correct French terms being analyzed. Content is intentionally complex, not corrupted.

pages_reviewed.rationale: This is an INDEX page. Evidence states 'INDEX page with proper names and references heavily corrupted. Names appear distorted.' Error rate 14.9%. For an index, accuracy of proper names is CRITICAL - this is the primary function. Any corruption in an index is more serious than in body text because indices are used for lookup/reference. Index entries must be exact. If proper names are corrupted, the index is non-functional. This justifies BAD classification regardless of whether body text with similar error rate might be marginal.
pages_reviewed.notes: Index page where name accuracy is critical. Corruption makes index unreliable for its primary reference function.

pages_reviewed.rationale: INDEX page continuation. Error rate 15.8% (highest). Evidence: 'Proper names corrupted: Jamblicus, Zeug, philosophical terms malformed.' For index pages, corruption of proper names and terms destroys functionality. Users rely on exact spellings for lookup. Even if some entries are correct, corrupted entries make the index partially non-functional. The purpose of an index demands higher accuracy standards than body text.
pages_reviewed.notes: Index page with corrupted proper names. Non-functional for reference purposes. Higher accuracy standard required.

pages_reviewed.rationale: INDEX page continuation. Error rate 15.9% (very high). Evidence: 'Author/reference names corrupted across entries.' Same rationale as previous index pages - proper name accuracy is essential for index functionality. Corrupted entries (Mallarmé, Ponge, Littré, Schapiro referenced) make the index unreliable. Cannot be used for its intended reference purpose.
pages_reviewed.notes: Index page with systematic corruption. Non-functional for reference lookup. Essential function compromised.

pages_reviewed.rationale: INDEX page conclusion. Error rate 11.4%. Evidence: 'Torok, Aletheia, Tisserant, Vernant entries compromised. While slightly better than previous index pages, still significantly degraded for index content.' Even at 'slightly better' quality, an index must be near-perfect for functionality. 11.4% error rate in an index means roughly 1 in 9 entries may be wrong - unacceptable for reference material. Users cannot trust lookups.
pages_reviewed.notes: Index page with degraded quality. Even 'better' index pages require near-perfect accuracy. Error rate too high for reliable reference use.

key_insights: Major source of false positives: Multilingual scholarly text with intentional German, French, and Greek terminology being classified as OCR errors
Index pages (397-400) legitimately classified as BAD due to higher accuracy requirements for reference functionality
Line break/hyphenation artifacts often miscounted as OCR corruption
Philosophical scholarship requires different evaluation criteria - technical terms in foreign languages are intentional
Systematic OCR artifacts (e.g., 'fl-' prefix pattern on p.382) represent genuine quality issues
Pages with genuine character substitution errors (vne→one, jjty, lnassive, oiw for Greek) are correctly classified BAD
Error rate calculations may be inflated when counting correct foreign-language terms as errors
Poetry/formatted text sections (p.97) legitimately problematic when formatting and diacritics lost
classification_guidelines_refined: Distinguish between intentional multilingual content and OCR corruption
Apply stricter standards to indices and reference materials than body text
Line break hyphenation artifacts alone do not justify BAD classification
Systematic OCR artifact patterns indicate processing failure
Character substitution errors (m→ln, Q→O, etc.) are genuine corruption
Foreign language terms should be verified in context before counting as errors
Poetry and formatted text requires preservation of formatting and diacritics
